description:
Anaerolentibacter hominis is a species of anaerobic, lenticular (lens-shaped) bacteria that was isolated from human clinical samples. Some key scientific characteristics of this species are as follows:

1. Taxonomy: Anaerolentibacter hominis belongs to the phylum Firmicutes, class Clostridia, order Clostridiales, and family Lachnospiraceae.

2. Cell Morphology: The cells are described as lens-shaped or lenticular, non-spore-forming, and non-motile.

3. Oxygen Requirement: Anaerolentibacter hominis is an obligate anaerobe, meaning it can only grow and thrive in the absence of oxygen.

4. Habitat and Isolation: This species has been isolated from human clinical samples, suggesting it is part of the normal human gut microbiome or can be associated with certain human health conditions.

5. Biochemical Characteristics: Anaerolentibacter hominis is saccharolytic, meaning it can ferment carbohydrates as a source of energy. It is also reported to be catalase-negative and indole-negative.

6. Genomic Features: The genome of Anaerolentibacter hominis has been sequenced, revealing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential roles in the human gut ecosystem.

Overall, Anaerolentibacter hominis is a recently described anaerobic bacterium that is part of the human gut microbiome and may have relevance to human health and disease, though its precise ecological functions and clinical significance are still under investigation.
